FieldValue.Value: Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery: age-standardized rate of CABG surgery performed on inpatients in acute care hospitals per 100,000 population age 20 and older.
Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI). Health indicators 2013: definitions, data sources and rationale. Ottawa (ON): Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI); 2013 May. 89 p.
ICD9CM: Aortocoronary bypass for heart revascularization, not otherwise specified (36.10)
MSH: Age Distribution ; Coronary Artery Bypass ; Coronary Artery Disease ; Inpatients ; Percutaneous Coronary Intervention
MTH: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery ; Coronary Artery Disease ; inpatient ; Percutaneous Coronary Intervention
SNOMEDCT_US: Acute care hospital ; Coronary artery bypass graft ; Disorder of coronary artery ; Inpatient ; Percutaneous coronary intervention
Related Population Health Measures: Population Use of Services
Does not apply to this measure
This measure is used to assess the age-standardized rate of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery performed on inpatients in acute care hospitals per 100,000 population age 20 and older.

Cardiac revascularization procedures are used to restore or improve blood supply to the heart muscle, which reduces the symptoms of coronary heart disease, such as chest pain and weakness. Revascularization can improve the quality of patients' lives and reduce mortality.

As with other types of surgical procedures, variation in coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery rates can be attributed to numerous factors, including differences in population demographics, physician practice patterns, and availability of services. In cases amenable to treatment with less invasive procedures percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), an alternative intervention to improve blood flow to the heart muscle, may be used. Variations in the extent to which PCI is utilized may result in variations in the rate of bypass surgery.

American College of Cardiology, American Heart Association, Eagle KA, Guyton RA, Davidoff R, Herrmann HC, Marlow RA, Nugent W, O'Connor GT, Orszulak TA, Rieselbach RE, Winters WL, Yusuf S, Gibbons RJ, Alpert JS, Garson A Jr, Gregoratos G, Russell RO, Ryan TJ, Smith SC Jr. ACC/AHA Guidelines for coronary artery bypass graft surgery: Executive summary and recommendations: A report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines. Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery
Total mid-year population age 20 and older
Total number of discharges for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) for inpatients age 20 and older (see the related "Numerator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

Field.Name: Type of Evidence Supporting the Criterion of Quality for the Measure

FieldValue.Value: A clinical practice guideline or other peer-reviewed synthesis of the clinical research evidence
A formal consensus procedure, involving experts in relevant clinical, methodological, public health and organizational sciences
A systematic review of the clinical research literature (e.g., Cochrane Review)
One or more research studies published in a National Library of Medicine (NLM) indexed, peer-reviewed journal

Field.Name: Additional Information Supporting Need for the Measure

FieldValue.Value:
• In Canada, the rates of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery declined—from 95.5 per 100,000 population in 1998–1999 to 62 per 100,000 in 2011–2012.
  • From 1998 to 2008,* the revascularization rate for males was about three times higher than the rate for females, although the rate of hospitalized heart attacks in males was only twice that of females.
  • Cardiac revascularization has been increasingly used to treat older patients. From 1998 to 2008,* rates of these procedures increased fourfold for patients 85 and older. Increases for other age groups ranged from 19% to 35%.

*Excluding Quebec.

Inclusions
Total mid-year population age 20 and older

Exclusions
Unspecified
not defined yet

Inclusions
Total number of discharges for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) for inpatients aged 20 and older

Note: Rates are based on the total number of discharges for CABG in a given year. Therefore, a patient who received more than one CABG procedure during the same hospitalization would be counted once.

Refer to the original measure documentation for the Canadian Classification of Diagnostic, Therapeutic, and Surgical Procedures (CCP) and Canadian Classification of Health Interventions (CCI) codes. Codes may be recorded in any position.

Exclusions
Procedures coded as out of hospital and abandoned after onset are excluded.

Note: CABG operations can only be performed in designated cardiac centres; therefore, procedures reported by facilities without on-site CABG services are excluded from the indicator calculation.

Field.Name: Description of Allowance for Patient or Population Factors

FieldValue.Value:
• Standardized rates are adjusted by age (collapsed to five-year groupings).
  • Indicators are calculated for provinces and territories as well as for health regions. Unless otherwise specified, data is reported based on the region of the patient's residence, not region of hospitalization.

This is the current release of the measure.

This measure updates a previous version: Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI). Health indicators 2012: definitions, data sources and rationale. Ottawa (ON): Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI); 2012 May. 93 p.

The measure developer reaffirmed the currency of this measure in July 2014.

The individual measure, "Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery Rate," is published in "Health Indicators 2013: Definitions, Data Sources and Rationale." This document is available in Portable Document Format (PDF) from the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) Web site.

For more information, contact CIHI at 4110 Yonge Street, Suite 300, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, M2P 2B7; Phone: 416-481-2002; Fax: 416-481-2950; E-mail: indicators@cihi.ca; Web site: www.cihi.ca.

The information was reaffirmed by the measure developer on July 11, 2014.
